column4: for a contested part of the route.""The project's current permits should be suspended and all construction stopped until a complete environmental and cultural review has been completed for the entire project

column6: Ed Markey
column7: Patrick Leahy and Benjamin Cardin.Also on Thursday
column8: the governments of 19 cities
column10: passed ordinances to support the Standing Rock tribe in opposition of the pipeline.In recent weeks
column11: protests against the Dakota Access pipeline led by the Standing Rock Sioux tribe in North Dakota have drawn international attention
column12: prompting the U.S. government to temporarily block construction on federal land. Tribal leaders say the pipeline will desecrate land and pollute water

column14: a sacred site. Opposition to the pipeline has drawn support from 200 Native American tribes.

column1: On Tuesday

column7: Amy Goodman

column9: said she would turn herself over to authorities in North Dakota on Monday morning
column10: in response to a criminal complaint was filed against her on Sept. 8 for trespassing.

column1: Goodman had filmed the crackdown on protesters by authorities last month.""I was doing my job as a journalist

column3: she said.When fully connected
column4: the 1
column5: 100-mile (1
column6: 770 km) pipeline would be the first to carry crude directly to the U.S. Gulf from the Bakken shale
column7: a vast oil formation in North Dakota
column8: Montana and parts of Canada.

column1: The $3.7 billion project is being built by the Dakota Access subsidiary of Dallas-based Energy Transfer Partners LP
column2: which has vowed to complete construction.""There must be a serious consideration of the full potential climate impacts of this pipeline prior to the Army Corps of Engineers approving any permits or easements for the Dakota Access pipeline

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-new-jersey-bridgegate-idUSKCN12D24Z	New Jersey citizen's 'Bridgegate' complaint against Christie can proceed: judge	"
By Joseph Ax
| PRINCETON
column2: N.J.

column1: PRINCETON
column2: N.J. A citizen's complaint against New Jersey Governor Chris Christie related to the ""Bridgegate"" lane-closure scandal can move forward
column3: a judge ruled on Thursday
column4: referring the case to state prosecutors to consider possible criminal charges.Roy McGeady
column5: the presiding judge for Bergen County municipal courts
column6: found probable cause for the criminal complaint filed last month by Bill Brennan
column7: an activist and retired firefighter
column8: a court official confirmed.The complaint of official misconduct accused Christie of knowing about a plot to close down lanes at the George Washington Bridge as an act of political payback. The governor has repeatedly denied any prior knowledge of the closures
column9: which created massive traffic jams in northern New Jersey.The ruling ratchets up the political pressure on Christie
column10: who became a major supporter of Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump after dropping his own White House bid and now heads his White House transition team.The controversy surrounding the scandal
column11: which has resulted in criminal charges against two of Christie's associates
column12: helped scuttle his bid for the Republican presidential nomination and has eroded the governor's approval ratings in New Jersey.The misconduct case now moves to the Bergen County Prosecutor's Office
column13: which will decide whether enough evidence exists to support a criminal charge. ""The office has no comment at this time
column14: spokeswoman Maureen Parenta said in an email.Brennan filed the complaint in municipal court in Fort Lee
column16: where Christie allies were accused of deliberately causing a massive traffic jam in September 2013 by closing access lanes to the George Washington Bridge in order to punish the town's mayor. The bridge is a major link to New York City.

column1: The two Christie associates - his former deputy chief of staff
column2: Bridget Kelly
column3: and former Port Authority of New York and New Jersey executive Bill Baroni - have been on trial in federal court in Newark
column4: New Jersey
column5: for their alleged roles in the scandal.Brennan's complaint was based on testimony from David Wildstein
column6: another Port Authority executive who pleaded guilty in the case and has been cooperating with prosecutors
column7: that Christie was aware of the lane closures at the time.A Christie spokesman
column8: Brian Murray
column9: said the governor would appeal the ruling immediately.

column1: This is a dishonorable complaint filed by a known serial complainant and political activist with a history of abusing the judicial system
column2: Murray said. ""The simple fact is the governor had no knowledge of the lane realignments either before they happened or while they were happening. This matter has already been thoroughly investigated by three separate independent investigations.""Brennan has filed numerous complaints
column3: as well as lawsuits
column4: against various officials in New Jersey over the years.Federal prosecutors have accused Kelly
column5: Baroni and Wildstein of orchestrating the lane closures to send a message to Fort Lee Mayor Michael Sokolich after the Democrat refused to endorse Christie's 2013 gubernatorial re-election campaign.At the time
column6: Christie was already eyeing a White House run
column7: and his advisers believed a show of bipartisan support would help enhance his national standing.

column1: Christie
column3: was among the 17 Republicans who originally vied for the Republican presidential nomination
column4: but he dropped out of the race in February after failing to gain traction in the early voting. He became one of eventual nominee Trump's staunchest supporters.As head of the New York businessman's transition team
column5: he would work to smooth the handover from Democratic President Barack Obama to Trump should Trump defeat Democrat Hillary Clinton in the Nov. 8 election.U.S. prosecutors are nearing the end of their case against Kelly and Baroni after four weeks of testimony. Lawyers for the two defendants have argued that virtually the entire Christie administration was aware of the scheme and have portrayed Kelly and Baroni as scapegoats.Both were expected to take the witness stand in their defense. (Reporting by Joseph Ax; Editing by Frank McGurty and Jonathan Oatis)"	['Obama'

By Alex Dobuzinskis

Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's support has sharply fallen in Utah where a poll on Wednesday showed him tied with Democrat Hillary Clinton in a state that has voted Republican in presidential races for decades.    The survey of 500 people from Salt Lake City-based Y2 Analytics also showed a surge for Evan McMullin
column2: an ex-CIA officer running as an independent.    Trump and Clinton were both at 26 percent while McMullin
column3: a member of the Mormon faith that dominates in Utah
column4: trailed just behind at 22 percent.The telephone poll of likely voters was conducted on Monday and Tuesday
column5: after a video featuring comments from Trump about groping women surfaced last week. The survey underscored the level of disaffection some conservatives have shown for Trump
column6: who has found himself at odds with much of the Republican Party establishment.

column1: The last time a Republican presidential nominee lost in Utah was in the landslide national election victory of President Lyndon Johnson
column2: a Democrat
column3: in 1964.""There's limits to partisanship even in Utah of all places
column4: Scott Riding
column5: managing partner of Y2 Analytics
column6: said.The poll results indicate severe erosion in Trump's popularity in Utah even as Clinton's support has grown slightly. A Salt Lake Tribune poll in September put support for Trump at 34 percent
column7: compared with 25 percent for Clinton.

column1: A number of prominent Utah Republicans
column2: including Governor Gary Herbert and U.S. Senator Mike Lee
column3: pulled their support for Trump or called on him to quit the race. McMullin
column4: a former CIA counter-terrorism specialist and investment banker whose campaign is based in Utah
column5: is less well known nationally than the other minor candidates
column6: Green Party nominee Jill Stein and Libertarian Party nominee Gary Johnson.Johnson ranked fourth in the Y2 Analytics poll with support from 14 percent of likely voters
column7: roughly in line with his previous level of support in Utah.

column1: McMullin
column2: who is running as a conservative independent
column3: is on the ballot in a dozen states including Utah
column4: with plans to expand his reach before the Nov. 8 election
column5: according to his campaign spokesman Rick Wilson. The vast majority of participants in the poll were familiar with the video tape of Trump's vulgar comments about women during a 2005 recording and a third of them said it lowered their opinion of the New York businessman.The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 4.38 percentage points. (Reporting by Alex Dobuzinskis in Los Angeles; Editing by Steve Gorman and Alistair Bell)"	['Clinton'

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-emails-idUSKCN12C2NM	Clinton aides sought to minimize fallout with White House on Keystone: emails	"
By Amanda Becker
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign looked for ways to avoid damaging its relationship with the White House as she considered how to publicly announce her position on the controversial Keystone XL pipeline
column2: according to emails published this week by WikiLeaks.Clinton aides weighed having the Democratic candidate say she opposed the pipeline in a closed-door union meeting
column3: leaking it to news media outlets or including it without fanfare in a policy fact sheet
column4: the emails show.Clinton eventually announced that she opposed the pipeline on Sept. 22
column6: at a town hall event in Des Moines
column7: Iowa
column8: early in the contest to win the Democratic presidential nomination. President Barack Obama
column10: announced that he too opposed the project on Nov. 6
column11: 2015.The WikiLeaks group released its latest batch of apparently hacked personal emails of Clinton campaign chair John Podesta on Wednesday
column12: just weeks before the Nov. 8 presidential election in which Clinton is facing Republican Donald Trump.Whether Clinton would oppose TransCanada Corp's pipeline to bring Canadian crude tar sands oil to refineries on the Gulf of Mexico was a major issue in her Democratic primary race against chief rival U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders
column13: who opposed the project.Clinton was walking a fine line on supporting or opposing the pipeline. The Keystone XL controversy put at odds labor unions
column14: which thought the project would spur job creation
column16: who advocated moving away from tar sands-derived oil to cleaner forms of energy.Clinton's decision was further complicated by the fact that the pipeline approval process began when she was Obama's secretary of state from 2009-2013. She said repeatedly that she would wait to announce her position until after the State Department had repeated its review of the project
column17: in deference to her former boss. Privately
column18: aides were figuring out the best way to announce her opposition to the project.

column1: We are trying to find a good way to leak her opposition to the pipeline without her having to actually say it and give up her principled stand about not second-guessing the President in public

column4: in one of the apparently hacked emails.Schwerin was responding to a suggestion by Clinton Campaign Manager Robby Mook that they could use the Keystone announcement to draw news media attention away from Clinton's use of a private email system while she headed the State Department.The Clinton campaign has declined to verify the authenticity of the Podesta emails released by WikiLeaks. column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-florida-registration-idUSKCN12C1Y2	Judge gives Florida voters more time to register after hurricane	"
By Joseph Ax

Florida residents were given six extra days to register to vote in the Nov. 8 election by a U.S. judge on Wednesday following the disruption triggered by powerful Hurricane Matthew in the state last week.U.S. District Judge Mark Walker in Tallahassee extended the registration deadline to Oct. 18 after the Florida Democratic Party sued to seek more time. The original deadline to register had been Tuesday
column2: before Walker ordered a one-day reprieve to allow for a hearing on Wednesday.Florida Democrats had argued that voters were forced to decide between their safety and their right to vote when Republican Governor Rick Scott ordered evacuations along a stretch of the state's Atlantic coast as Matthew approached. ""No right is more precious than having a voice in our democracy
column3: Walker wrote in a three-page court ruling on the lawsuit.Florida is a battleground state in the Nov. 8 presidential election pitting Democrat Hillary Clinton against Republican Donald Trump
column4: with opinion polls showing a close race there. It is the largest of the hotly contested states whose populations can swing either to Republicans or Democrats and thus play a decisive role.The powerful hurricane
column5: which killed around 1
column6: 000 people in Haiti as it churned through the Caribbean
column7: is blamed for at least 30 deaths in Florida
column8: Georgia
column9: South Carolina and North Carolina. North Carolina now faces flooding from swollen rivers.

column1: In its complaint

column3: noting that populations that lean Democratic
column4: including minorities and younger voters
column5: register in greater numbers just before the deadline. It also noted that areas affected by Matthew have substantial populations of black and Latino voters who would be disproportionately likely to register to vote at the last minute.In past presidential years
column6: up to 20 percent of all new registrations in Florida were filed during the week before the deadline
column7: according to the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University School of Law
column8: which helped bring the lawsuit.

column2: today's ruling is a major victory for all Floridians and for the democratic process in the Sunshine State
column3: the state Democratic Party said in a statement.The judge earlier ruled that Florida law did not give Scott authority to extend voter registration and that he was not a proper party to the case.Florida Secretary of State Ken Detzner
column4: a Scott appointee also named in the lawsuit
column5: was empowered to do so

column3: while Georgia declined to do so. North Carolina will not extend the regular deadline to register to vote
column4: which ends on Friday
